threads.title: Quick Clarification: Do you need to destroy a building when at 0 People?

posts.author: werefish
posts.body:
The game ends when you have have negative people and can't destroy any buildings to bring you back up to the positives, or when you have no people and no buildings left; I get that. Do you have to destroy a building when you hit 0 though, or are you good at 'full employment' so long as nothing puts your people count into the negative?

I presume you don't since I didn't see anything in the rules saying you did, but thought it worth double checking here.

Thanks!

posts.author: Ditocoaf
posts.body:
EDIT: I misunderstood the question, see posts below. I don't think my post here is incorrect, it's just not answering the right question.

The rules instruct you to keep losing buildings until you have enough people tokens to lose what you're supposed to. It's after that section that it says "if you have to lose more people than you can, your moon colony has failed. The game is over." I'd say that you have to lose all your buildings on your way to that loss state.

The intention seems pretty clear to me that the player triggering the end of the game has zero people left, and shouldn't have leftover people (via tokens or buildings) to potentially win over someone who paid their losses in full. You don't get to say "I don't have that many to lose, so the game ends before I lose anything". Though I do see how you could interpret the rules that way.

posts.author: nahtaivel
posts.body: You only destroy a building when you need to spend the population and you don't have it.  Keep going with 0 people and 1 or more buildings until you encounter the next card requiring them.

posts.author: Ditocoaf
posts.body:
On reread, I think Alan understood Benjamin's question and I didn't.

Benjamin, it's helpful to think of your "people" as including both tokens and buildings. It's just that, if you would have to lose any people in a building, you lose the building first.

posts.author: werefish
posts.body: No problem. Thanks for the answers guys!

posts.author: donaldx
posts.body: You lose the game at zero people, not at negative people. Even zero people with a Flag loses. This seems clear in the rulebook.

posts.author: Ditocoaf
posts.body:
donaldx wrote:

You lose the game at zero people, not at negative people. Even zero people with a Flag loses. This seems clear in the rulebook.

Here's what I think the OP's question actually is:

"Say I have three people on my playmat and also some buildings. A card makes me lose three people. Do I need to destroy a building to gain some people on my playmat, since otherwise I would have zero of them."

And I'm sure the answer to that is "no, not yet, it's fine to have zero people tokens, as long as you still have people in buildings and don't have to lose more yet."

threads.title: Why are new twists or robots added to the draw pile rather than revealed immediately?

posts.author: rhi_zome
posts.body: I'm sure there's some case where it matters, but I haven't run into one yet.

posts.author: Ah_Pook
posts.body: If multiple things are added to the draw pile simultaneously you shuffle them and resolve them in random order. It can matter sometimes.

posts.author: Ditocoaf
posts.body:
rhi_zome wrote:

I'm sure there's some case where it matters, but I haven't run into one yet.

Partly, because if multiple cards are added during the same Work turn, you want to shuffle them together to randomize the order they happen in. Three players might each build something that adds a Robot, a Perk, and a Development all at the same time, and you need to shuffle those together on the top of the deck.

So then, it's simpler to use the same procedure every time, instead of writing the rules differently for different card types or situations.

posts.author: donaldx
posts.body:
Ditocoaf wrote:

rhi_zome wrote:

I'm sure there's some case where it matters, but I haven't run into one yet.

Partly, because if multiple cards are added during the same Work turn, you want to shuffle them together to randomize the order they happen in. Three players might each build something that adds a Robot, a Perk, and a Development all at the same time, and you need to shuffle those together on the top of the deck.

So then, it's simpler to use the same procedure every time, instead of writing the rules differently for different card types or situations.

Correct. It's simplest to have one rule that always applies; and usually multiple cards can be added at once, and they need an ordering.

threads.title: [WIP] Fallout Vault-Tec retheme of Moon Colony Bloodbath [30% done]

posts.author: DrHenryArmitage
posts.body:
Retheme #33

My retheme geeklist: Martin Has Fallen Down The Retheme Rabbit Hole

Blame this one on Nathan Flickner. This one wasn't even on my radar until he put the idea in my head.

There's a long backstory to this retheme project involving 3-4 different games, and 2-3 different theme topics, that is too weird and winding and convoluted for me to get into here. Suffice to say, this is where I've landed: this game, but in the retro-futuristic, overly optimistic world of Vault-Tec propaganda, with Vault Boy and other vault dwellers playing a starring role in the inevitable demise of their vaults, their air supplies, their resources, and ultimately, their lives.

First up, we need some Vault Overseer Player Boards, in the classic PiPBoy style. My thinking here was to use 4 cubes to keep track of actions, instead of the action tokens in the original game. Place the cube on the action you wish to take, then after performing the action, move the cube to its spot on the track.



Then I worked on the 20 Robot cards. Just an opportunity to have some fun with the Overseer typeface, the card image, and using Multideck to embed inline images into the card effect text. Much better now that Rick Holzgrafe has added the ability to adjust the size of the inline images.



The plan is to keep the art style clean and cartoonish, with brightly colored foreground characters and elements, with darker, more drab vault backgrounds. Keeping the optimistic Vault-Tec propaganda vibe in the card titles and flavor text (reminiscent as well of Lumon's CorpSpeak in Severance).

Hunger card = Rationing Opportunity
Leak = Radiation Integrity Drill
Accident = Spontaneous Workplace Adventure (SWA)
Power Failure = Energy Conservation Challenge

Etcetera.

No joke, you really do. I'm not suggesting that you want to do any such thing; I'm just pointing out what I can actually personally offer you.

posts.author: thecorsetmaker
posts.body:
To be fair, I have yet to watch the Dice Tower video (it's in the queue and I've been quite busy of recent), but it has been documented (see various writings from Geoff Engelstein, among others) that the setting and implementation of certain mechanisms can have a large impact on how one perceives a game. Perhaps that is the case for this game and how Tom feels about it.

As a simple example: We tend to feel quite differently about a game that requires you to spend resources each round or lose points versus one that requites us to spend a number of resources each round to gain points. Same effect, completely different feel, but one might implement either one depending upon the setting (or as some say 'theme') of the game.

posts.author: JupiterJonesJJ
posts.body:
I am also curious about the solo mode. I absolutely love Revive and mostly play it solo. But I was not so happy with the solo mode. The base game solo rules made it much too easy to max out everything pretty soon once you found the trick with the card combos. This was improved slightly by rule modifications and challenges in the expansion. But what really made a huge difference for me were the fan-made automa variants "Mautoma" and "The Automatons". They give you some competition on the board, while keeping the administrative effort to a minimum. This allows for s pretty good simulation of two or even multi player game.
My big wish for Recall would be to include a really very good solo mode or even such an automa right from the beginning. Are there any plans going in this direction?
Looking forward to hearing more details on the game and its solo mode!

By the way, Recall is also my most anticipated game of the year ðŸ˜€


One thing I think is amazing about Revive is how modular it is. 2p can be low interaction, but it's easy enough to take out a portion of the map (e.g. along a diagonal) to make it more interactive. I've played mostly at 4p, but have multiple games at all counts.

Also very much looking forward to this one.

In the description of the game we are playing as a tribe, something this game shares with Revive (along with the same four designers). For those of us who know (and adore) Revive, will some of these tribes be familiar to us? Are we playing in the same world?

As much as I hate to admit it, it took my 9-year-old daughter looking at my screen to point out that both Revive and Recall start with 'Re' and have the same number of letters.

posts.author: Anaesthetic
posts.body:
There are 14 tribes in Recall. All new.
Each tribe has one signature ability, and you also begin the game with a gadget. Both your tribe and gadget provides powerful abilities that influences you strategy. During the game you may acquire up to three more gadgets. You do this by gathering knowledge about three ancient civilizations, copying their gadgets, and possibly also their tribe ability. This way you build a unique combination of one tribe + four gadgets.

And then we have this optional feature: At the end of the game, you can register your tribe in the online archive, so that other players can discover your unique build as an ancient civilization in their own game.

posts.author: O_Gama
posts.body:
Itâ€™s rare to find a game that does exactly what it promisesâ€”and Cascadia nails it. From the moment you see that cover art whispering â€œharmony with nature,â€ you know youâ€™re in for a calm, satisfying experience.

When you sit down to play, you find a serene puzzleâ€¦ until that perfect combo of salmon tokens lands on the board. You know it isnâ€™t actually the optimal play for your wife, but somehow she snags that salmon first and you realize even indirect competition can sting. Ten seconds later the frustation disappears as you realize thereâ€™s always another tile waiting. The game is smart enough to steer you clear of truly dead-end draws, so you never feel hopelessly stuck.




Components get top marks from the tarot-sized cards, the high quality habitat tiles to the chunky animal tokens. My only nitpick? The insert is terrible. I still canâ€™t figure out the â€œcorrectâ€ way to pack it all awayâ€”strangely ironic for a game where everything else fits so perfectly.

The gameplay is every bit as satisfying as expected. Matching terrain types and placing animals feels intuitive, yet thereâ€™s enough depth in planning your cascades to keep you hooked for hours. Itâ€™s not going to replace your all-time favorite, but itâ€™s the perfect Sunday-afternoon pick-up-and-play that never overstays its welcome.

What really surprised me, though, is the replayability. Youâ€™d think a family-oriented puzzle would go stale fast, but the ever-shifting scoring cards for each animal ensure youâ€™re always chasing a fresh goal. No two games ever feel the same.


---

Presentation - 10
Engagement - 7
Gameplay - 9
Value - 8

> Final Score: 8.5 / 10




---

Wrap-Up:
Cascadia isnâ€™t an earth-shattering epic, but itâ€™s the ideal mood-makerâ€”perfect for a rainy Sunday or dialing down the tension after a cut-throat session. Itâ€™s elegant, approachable and cleverly designed to keep you coming back for another game.

threads.title: Rules for valid salmon shapes; why doesn't shape matter?

posts.author: wbothfeld
posts.body:
A lot of posts indicate that salmon can be in any shape in a run, as long as touching only two other salmon.

My question is, if shape doesn't matter, why do other cards (like bear and elk) indicate that any shape can be used, but the salmon cards don't? Wouldn't that mean that the salmon need to be in the run shape depicted on each card?

Secondly, CARD E is literally titled Zig-Zag run, so wouldn't that indicate that it has to be in a zig-zag shape?

Thanks for clarifications.

posts.author: ColtsFan76
posts.body:
wbothfeld wrote:

A lot of posts indicate that salmon can be in any shape in a run, as long as touching only two other salmon.

My question is, if shape doesn't matter, why do other cards (like bear and elk) indicate that any shape can be used, but the salmon cards don't? Wouldn't that mean that the salmon need to be in the run shape depicted on each card?

Because each animal has different scoring conditions. Sometimes shape matters, sometimes it doesn't. Salmon is already restricted in that the runs only count as long as each doesn't connect to more than 2 others. Hawks are even more "goofy" in how they have to sight each other and be so far away. It is just what gives variety to the scoring and how you have to plan for multiple things to maximize placement for scoring.

Secondly, CARD E is literally titled Zig-Zag run, so wouldn't that indicate that it has to be in a zig-zag shape?

Typically names are just thematic. What is important is the clarifications which for this card says must match exact shape - or the mirror of. So yes, it does need to be in a zig-zag shape.

threads.title: How do you score Salmon Gathering card?

posts.author: hellodendy
posts.body:
In the example shown on the card is the player going to score 12 points (1+3+3+5)?
And then in the example I have set up is the score: 5 (fox) + 5 (bear) + 5 (bear) + 3 hawk) + 5 (elk) = 23 points?
It seems like using too many salmon becomes wasteful. The three salmon do not score any points?

posts.author: Ouduk
posts.body: You are correct for both. A longer than 3 salmon run just gives you more opportunities to have other adjacent animals.

posts.author: hellodendy
posts.body: Great, thanks for the help!

posts.author: TK_422
posts.body:
I have it at 18 pts.
Score card has group size 3+.
The 6 bears would be 1 group.

posts.author: hellodendy
posts.body: Yes, I see that now. I would have needed a gap between a group of 3. Thanks.

posts.author: g_chahowskoi
posts.body: My interpretation is that the Salmon do not score, only the SIZE of each group that is adjacent. In the above case 14 (6 Bear + 3 Fox + 3 Elk + 2 Hawks). Maybe I'm wrong, but this is my understanding of that "Gathering" card.

posts.author: CavemanLogic
posts.body:
g_chahowskoi wrote:

My interpretation is that the Salmon do not score, only the SIZE of each group that is adjacent.


Yes, that's correct. The salmon themselves *don't* score. You only score the adjacent groups of other animals *surrounding* the salmon.

g_chahowskoi wrote:

In the above case 14 (6 Bear + 3 Fox + 3 Elk + 2 Hawks). Maybe I'm wrong, but this is my understanding of that "Gathering" card.


The example shown scores 18 points. The example shows a group of 2 Hawks, 3 Elk, 3 Foxes, and 6 Bears. According to the chart on the card, the Hawks will score 3 points for having a group size of "2", while the other three groups will score 5 points each for having a group size of "3+". Note that the group of 6 Bears falls into the category of "group size of 3+ scores 5 Points" so the Bears will only score 5 points even though there are 6 of them in the group.

As noted in a previous reply above, if the Bears had been separated into two different non-adjacent groups of 3 Bears each, then *both* of those groups would have scored 5 points each.

The correct answer is 18.

Cheers!

threads.title: Can I play more than one card in a single action?

posts.author: PlayerDimg71
posts.body:
Hello.
I'm a new Everdell player and I want to ask you if I can play more than one card in a single action. Even if I have the necessary resources. Iâ€™m not talking about the free construction of critters.

posts.author: vilnai
posts.body: No. Generally speaking, your turn is either placing a worker or playing a card. Even if it's playing a critter for free, you can't also play another card that turn by paying resources.

posts.author: odie73
posts.body:
In general? No. See pages 7 and 9 of the base game rulebook:
Page 7: Play proceeds clockwise. You will take turns performing one of the following actions. These actions may be performed in any order, but only one action may be taken per turn.
Place a Worker
or Play a Card
or Prepare for Season.

Page 9: You may play one card.

The "one" is specifically bolded in the rules.

posts.author: masaokano
posts.body:
I believe the only exceptions in the base game would be if you:

1. Play a Postal Pigeon, which allows you to play a card as the card ability
2. You play a Ranger and move it to a location that allows you to play a card (draw two meadow cards and play 1 for -1 any resource)

But again, this isnâ€™t taking a second â€œplay a cardâ€ action, you are simply fulfilling the card ability of a played card.

Jos Farawayssa on jo tÃ¤hÃ¤n mennessÃ¤ riittÃ¤nyt pohdittavaa, niin erityisen maukkaan lisÃ¤sÃ¤vÃ¤yksen antaa pelin pisteytys, jossa piileekin Farawayn kiehtovuus. threads.title: Review: Still fun after ten plays? My pros and cons

posts.author: Olafslomp
posts.body:
Even though long extensive reviews seem to be the most popular reviews on BGG, I myself just don't have the time or the patience to read those.
I prefer quick overviews where I can get some insights into why this game may or may not be attractive to me.
My reviews are targeted at a similar audience, and just consist of my pros and cons coming from:
1) First impressions (before playing my first game)
2) Impressions after the first game
3) Current feelings (after at least 10 plays)

First impressions:
+ This has been on BGGâ€™s list of most played games for quite a while (11 months and counting, currently still in the top 10), any game that is that popular amongst BGG members has my attention
+ One of my fellow guild members brought this to our first meet-up with members from our GCC Guild, I was more than happy to give this a try
- There doesnâ€™t seem to be much of a theme in this one â€“ I do prefer games with a theme
+/- The artwork is simple but colourful and effective


Impressions after the first game:
+ The main mechanism is an interesting new find; play cards with scoring conditions in anticipation of the other cards you will be playing, this requires a combination of some realistic planning and a bit of push your luck (eg play a card that will score a number points if there are three thistles on the rest of the cards you will play, without knowing what cards will come up, but taking into account the odds of these showing up)
+/- I like drafting, but am not big fan of set collection, so a bit of a mixed bag of mechanisms for my taste
+ 15-30 minutes (as listed on the box) really means 15-30 minutes in this case, which makes it a good candidate for a filler or for a short game to end a gaming evening

Current feelings (10 plays into it):
- Thereâ€™s not much depth in this, after a couple of plays the basic approach is pretty clear and it becomes mostly a game of luck (with the decision space mainly being how hard you want to push your luck)
+ This plays fine at all player counts, with quick snappy turns that prevent any significant down time. With more players it does feel like thereâ€™s a bit less luck, as there are more cards to choose from every turn, especially if you get to play early in the round, so a higher chance of getting what you are planning/hoping for.
+ The tension that lies in hoping to draw what you need in those last cards is always fun
+ As I was originally taught this game, I only saw the rulebook after I had already played it several times. I was positively surprised to find a quite long description of the theme, regarding the lands you walk through, the inhabitants and the wildlife. The theme doesnâ€™t really shine through, Iâ€™m sorry to say, but I do appreciate the effort that was put into creating a bit of theme for the game.

End conclusion (well, for now):
I enjoyed my plays of this, and Iâ€™ll happily play this when somebody suggests it, but I donâ€™t feel a need to own this myself. Itâ€™s just not deep enough for a thinky game and not fun enough for a party game imho to beat some of the better games in my collection that this would be fighting with for table time.




If you'd like to read more of my reviews, check out Still fun after ten plays? - All reviews

AAbouzeid wrote:

I agree about the theme but the art here, for me, really makes up for it.

I think that for the OP to dismiss this game's artwork as "simple" is to really do it a disservice. I do appreciate that art is 'in the eye of the beholder' but its not arguable that a significant effort went into the design and integration of the artwork and graphic components into the game. It also strikes me as being really original i.e. not just a rehash of common fantasy or even 'ancient civilisation' styles. The designer diary - https://boardgamegeek.com/blog/1/blogpost/169018/artist-diar... - is well worth a read!

Disclaimer: as someone who grew up playing boardgames in the 70's and 80's I am continuously amazed and appreciative of how much more of a presence of excellent art and graphic design there is in today's games. Maybe I am not just cynical or critical enough...

Bigjoeyd wrote:

The whole idea of the weight rating is that itâ€™s an indication for the combination of depth and complexity.
Eg Go is a very â€œsimpleâ€ game when it comes to the amount of rules, but (rightfully so) has a weight rating of almost 4.

posts.author: astroglide
posts.body:
Olafslomp wrote:

Eg Go is a very â€œsimpleâ€ game when it comes to the amount of rules, but (rightfully so) has a weight rating of almost 4.

Yet Poker is somehow only a 2.43. And the BGG definition of weight leads with

"Weight" isn't clearly defined. (For a while game pages described it as a "complexity rating" with a brief mouseover explanation "Community rating for how difficult a game is to understand. Lower rating (lighter weight) means easier.")...

Perhaps best to not rely on it to prove or disprove very much.

posts.author: Olafslomp
posts.body:
astroglide wrote:

Olafslomp wrote:

Eg Go is a very â€œsimpleâ€ game when it comes to the amount of rules, but (rightfully so) has a weight rating of almost 4.

Yet Poker is somehow only a 2.43. And the BGG definition of weight leads with

"Weight" isn't clearly defined. (For a while game pages described it as a "complexity rating" with a brief mouseover explanation "Community rating for how difficult a game is to understand. Lower rating (lighter weight) means easier.")...

Perhaps best to not rely on it to prove or disprove very much.


Poker is an interesting example. Purely based on complexity and depth, I think 2.5-ish sounds right to me.
But this does not really take into account the whole social interaction part, which is hard to include in the weight.
But itâ€™s always possible to find some exceptions to try to disprove a general rule.

Just because BGG doesnâ€™t have a proper definition doesnâ€™t mean that Weight is not well defined. There are plenty of places where Weight is well described, here for instance: https://chitsandgiggles.games/understanding-board-game-weigh...
And in general, my experience is that the voice of the masses work pretty well on BGG, in that the average weight rating tends to give a pretty a good indication of what to expect. (Of course this does not work with games that only have received a small number of weight votes), while also showing that individual opinions will vary.
What Iâ€™m saying is that my personal opinion - or that of the two people arguing that this game is much deeper, or of the couple of people that have commented that they agree with me - probably bears less weight than that of the BGG masses. In general, they give a pretty decent indication of weight via the BGG weight rating.
But sure, if you donâ€™t trust the BGG community to give you a proper indication of weight, then the weight rating becomes useless and takes away the one semi-neutral â€œfactâ€ to use in a discussion between two people over whether a game is deep or not.
Than we can only settle on agreeing to disagree.

posts.author: BlackSheep
posts.body:
The problem is that weight is a single number trying to represent two things which aren't necessarily connected - depth of strategy, and complexity of rules. Most people would say Hive is a deeper game than Arkham Horror, but has a much lower weight (2.31 vs 3.59) because of rules complexity. Heck, Betrayal at the House on the Hill has a higher weight than Hive, and that's purely a game of rolling dice and pulling cards and seeing what happens.

There's been some interesting analysis and discussion about separating out the two axes over the years. For example:
https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/200613/weight-depth-vs-co...
https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/354554/rules-complexity-a...

posts.author: TheTroublewithForest

threads.title: Yellow Railroad starting options, yet again

posts.author: cdunc123
posts.body:
Here is the text from the Ride the Rails rulebook about placing the Yellow Railroad:
In the third round of play, the Yellow Railroad becomes available.
This Railroad must start in Chicago and/or in one of the three
westernmost occupied cities. Prior to building, the westernmost
city must have one, and only one, locomotive in the hex; Chicago,
as usual, may hold any number. Which cities are westernmost is
determined the moment the first Yellow locomotive would be
placed on the game board.


Here is the text from the Winsome Games version (i.e. Rail USA):
This railroad must start in one [of] the three westernmost cities that has a railroad and only one railroad in the hex, or Chicago. Which cities are westernmost is judged at the moment the first yellow cube is placed.

There have been two helpful threads clarifying some questions about these rules, hereand here.

But as I read things, we still lack an official ruling about the special case in which Chicago has exactly one train in it and moreover, Chicago is one of "the three westernmost cities that has a railroad and only one railroad in the hex." How do we read the rule in that case? In particular, is it...

The stricter interpretation: Your choices = [Chicago, westernmost 1-railroad city A, westernmost 1-railroad city B] OR [Chicago] -- so, just three cities to choose from.

The looser interpretation: Your choices = [westernmost 1-railroad non-Chicago city A, westernmost 1-railroad non-Chicago city B, westernmost 1-railroad non-Chicago city C] OR [Chicago]

With the looser interpretation, a player has four cities to choose from for the starting position of the Yellow Railroad. With the stricter interpretation, a player can sometimes have just three cities to choose from, namely, in the special case where Chicago itself is one of "the three westernmost cities that has a railroad and only one railroad in the hex."

It's not clear to me what the best interpretation is. I agree the stricter interpretation is the more literal interpretation. But I also find it easy to imagine that the designer/publisher always intended for there to be four choices of starting city and just didn't notice the possibility of a strictly literal interpretation.

Maybe we will get an official ruling on this. But in the mean time, below is a poll to take. (Side note: for purposes of this poll, let's ignore a case in which more than three cities are tied for "westernmost.")

[poll=2090314]
If you choose "something else," please let us know in a comment what that something else is.

posts.author: branstonoriginal
posts.body:
Hopefully, John will chime in here and let us know, but for now I favour the looser interpretation.
In most cases, I'd usually vote for a stricter definition, but in this case I see Chicago as a kind of 'special city' and, as such, is removed from consideration when defining "westernmost".

posts.author: cdunc123
posts.body:
branstonoriginal wrote:

Hopefully, John will chime in here and let us know, but for now I favour the looser interpretation.
In most cases, I'd usually vote for a stricter definition, but in this case I see Chicago as a kind of 'special city' and, as such, is removed from consideration when defining "westernmost".

FWIW this is my favorite interpretation and rationale too.

posts.author: WilbertK
posts.body: This is the post that settles it for me.

posts.author: cdunc123
posts.body:
WilbertK wrote:

This is the post that settles it for me.

The second half of that post clearly favors what I have called the â€œstricterâ€ (i.e. literal) interpretation.

But since the poster is not (as far as I know) associated with Capstone Games, and since the argument there is essentially â€œthis is what follows if you take the rule literally,â€ I personally donâ€™t regard the post as a definitive answer to the question, â€œDoes interpreting this rule literally reflect the designerâ€™s true intent?â€

However, itâ€™s a subjective judgment call, so YMMV.

posts.author: bookermanpries
posts.body: So I strongly dislike the "and/or" phrasing in the RtR rules, since I don't think it creates a distinction, but why would it be there if not to signal that Chicago may be part of the 3 westernmost cities and should be included within the count?

posts.author: branstonoriginal
posts.body:
bookermanpries wrote:

So I strongly dislike the "and/or" phrasing in the RtR rules, since I don't think it creates a distinction, but why would it be there if not to signal that Chicago may be part of the 3 westernmost cities and should be included within the count?


I agree, it's the worst.
But broken down:

A. This Railroad must start in Chicago and in one of the three westernmost occupied cities.

B. This Railroad must start in Chicago or in one of the three westernmost occupied cities.

Option A doesn't make any sense, but in both cases Chicago appears to be distinctly separated from the 3 cities?

Ultimately, while I find this interesting from an English language and rules editing point of view, I don't think playing by one interpretation or another will make a huge difference to gameplay.
The looser interpretation does give a player more flexibility in making those connections, which you could argue is core to the game?

posts.author: bookermanpries
posts.body:
branstonoriginal wrote:

bookermanpries wrote:

So I strongly dislike the "and/or" phrasing in the RtR rules, since I don't think it creates a distinction, but why would it be there if not to signal that Chicago may be part of the 3 westernmost cities and should be included within the count?


I agree, it's the worst.
But broken down:

A. This Railroad must start in Chicago and in one of the three westernmost occupied cities.

B. This Railroad must start in Chicago or in one of the three westernmost occupied cities.

Option A doesn't make any sense, but in both cases Chicago appears to be distinctly separated from the 3 cities?

Ultimately, while I find this interesting from an English language and rules editing point of view, I don't think playing by one interpretation or another will make a huge difference to gameplay.
The looser interpretation does give a player more flexibility in making those connections, which you could argue is core to the game?


I agree, fwiw, about the looser interpretation being favourable.

Where I was coming from was the following sequence of thought:
A) The and/or phrasing seems to imply with the "and" that the yellow railroad can start in two cities simultaneously, which is definitely wrong.
B) The looser interpretation is easy to clear up: "This railroad must start in one [of] the three westernmost cities that has a railroad and only one railroad in the hex (not including Chicago), or Chicago."
C) So it seemed quite possible to me that the reversal of sequencing, putting Chicago before the westernmost cities, and the inclusion of an "and/or" (excellent TV series on Disney btw) statement was an attempt to impose a stricter clarification.

This is speculative of course!

posts.author: cdunc123
posts.body:
I agree that the "and/or" is far from clear. All interpretations of it are going to be strained in some way.
This Railroad must start in Chicago and/or in one of the three
westernmost occupied cities.

One way of reading this is as elliptical for:
This Railroad must start in one of the following set: Chicago and/or in one of the three westernmost occupied cities.

Breaking this down =

â­This Railroad must start in one of the following set: {Chicago, westernmost 1, westernmost 2, and westernmost 3}
â­This Railroad must start in one of the following set: {Chicago, westernmost 1, westernmost 2, or westernmost 3}

These mean the same thing, which makes "and/or" unnecessary but harmless.

I'm not saying that this is necessarily the correct reading. It's just *a* way of reading the confusing wording. As I said above, the interpretation boils down to a subjective judgment call.

EDIT: Oops, I had failed to spot Tomâ€™s post above when I wrote this. I agree that the â€œand/orâ€ is either careless, or a clumsy attempt to impose the stricter reading. Iâ€™m not sure which! The point of my post here is just to say, â€œHere is one way the â€˜and/orâ€™ could be merely careless, nothing more.â€

threads.title: If Placing a Train on a mountain hex, what happens to the unsued train?

posts.author: ThePes
posts.body: A quick question here that I wasn't able to answer from the rule book; when placing a train on a mountain hex, you lose a train from your batch (if you have 5 to place, a mountain hex placement reduces it to 4).  The question is, what happens to that extra train?  Does it go away from the game or does it go back to the general supply?

posts.author: Mayaheine
posts.body:
From PHASE 2: Build Railroad Track:

If a player builds track in a Mountain hex (or hexes), the total number of locomotives able to be placed by that player is reduced by one.



Effectively, the "lost" train is returned to the supply. The way the rule reads is that if you build into mountains you treat the number of available trains as being one lower than normal for your player count.

posts.author: ThePes
posts.body:
Okay, the rules feel a bit criptic about it, and it implies you have to announce your intentions before picking up your alloted trains.

Thanks for the info.

posts.author: Mayaheine
posts.body: Agreed, it's not as clear as it might be.  The intent seems obvious, and the playthroughs I've seen all play it as "take the number of trains indicated and then return one if they build into mountains".  I normally play it that way.  It certainly seems possible to announce that you're building into mountains and take one fewer, though, if you're doing any sort of planning ahead.

posts.author: ThePes
posts.body: Hopefully they do a small errata on future printings and just add "...return any unused trains to the supply".

posts.author: branstonoriginal
posts.body:
To reduce errata, a change of perspective may help:

There is an option to build track, from 0 locomotives up to the maximum allowance dictated by player count.

Building into mountains reduces the allowance.

(While players may pick up the locomotives to help think through their building, handling the locomotives before their placement is not part of the game rules ðŸ™‚)

threads.title: Do parallel links pay out to both companies?

posts.author: mediaisrelative
posts.body: Most hexes can hold two trains, same with cities. If I build parallel along my opponent's line would both links pay out if I then ride the rails across said links? So for example, my opponent has connected Cincinnati and St. Louis with orange. I build exactly along their track with black and then when it comes time to ride the rails, I ride it along those links. Black and orange would then both pay out, right? Or does a different scenario come up? I couldn't find a thread or rules clarification about this.

posts.author: Murr
posts.body:
mediaisrelative wrote:

Most hexes can hold two trains, same with cities. If I build parallel along my opponent's line would both links pay out if I then ride the rails across said links? So for example, my opponent has connected Cincinnati and St. Louis with orange. I build exactly along their track with black and then when it comes time to ride the rails, I ride it along those links. Black and orange would then both pay out, right? Or does a different scenario come up? I couldn't find a thread or rules clarification about this.
You only ride along a single color between cities and cannot loop back to include the same hex more than once. Rules read (emphasis mine):

The player must be able to trace a route of locomotives from the Passengerâ€™s starting city to their ending city via Links. A Link is a path of locomotives belonging to a single Railroad that connects two cities.
. . .
No looping is allowedâ€”each hex may only be visited once during the journey. Additionally, the player decides through which Railroadâ€™s Links the Passenger travels.

posts.author: Prop_Joe
posts.body:
You're only activating one color during delivery.

A Link is a path of locomotives belonging to a single Railroad that connects two cities.


So parallel would be two links, one for each color/railroad.

Edit: Beaten to it.

posts.author: mediaisrelative
posts.body: Wonderful, thank you.

posts.author: Jon_Stern
posts.body:
I read the related threads and do not see an answer to this specific question (sorry if I missed it). I have not played yet, but want to make sure I know what to do if it comes up.

From what I understand, the 12/8 bonus is determined when the connection is made. That makes sense if one track is heading east from a purple city and another is heading west.

However, what happens if there is a multi-railway route that started in the east and heads west. Then eventually, after multiple connections reaches a purple city. At the time the transcontinental is completed, it is due to a western extension, not a new connection. If there are 3 railways on the route, and one connection is in a city while the other is in a rural hex, how do you determine the bonus? In this case, would it be the westernmost connection? Or do you have to track the timestamp of every railway connection in case it eventually heads west and forms a transcontinental?

posts.author: liketheboys
posts.body:
In the Capstone rules, I understand it to be that, as soon as you place a track that bridges a western city (purple/black) with an eastern city (six multi-colored), you get either $12 if the bridging track was in a city, or $8 elsewhere.

I didn't understand the scenario you described tho, sorry /: Maybe you could show us in a picture?

posts.author: Jon_Stern
posts.body: The scenario is when the final bridging track is placed in the purple city itself. This final track placement is completing the transcontinental but isn't connecting two different railways. I can set up a picture later if that's not clear.

posts.author: liketheboys
posts.body:
Ahhhh yeah I see.

The rule goes:

The first player to make a Transcontinental connectionâ€”where a line of track comprised of different Railroads connects a West Coast Purple & Black city to one of the six multi-colored East Coast citiesâ€”immediately receives the Transcontinental bonus.


It doesn't matter how you do it, the important thing if you need "a line of track" connecting the East and West. If you have a long stretch of track coming from an Eastern city and eventually touching down to a Western (purple/black) city, then at that moment you have met those conditions and done so by placing a track in a city.

I think the confusion stems from the graphic they use to represent it (with one track bridging existing track on both sides). It does a good job of conveying the general idea, but unfortunately that edge case does slip through.

posts.author: Jon_Stern
posts.body:
Ok. I'm also looking at the Capstone rules. The confusing part for me was the next sentence after the part you quoted:

"If the Railroads connect in a city hex, the bonus is $12. However, if the
Railroads connect in any other hex, the bonus is $8. The Transcontinental
bonus is only paid once and to the player who makes the connection."

It seems like the key is based on where the connection between railroads is made, not where the final track is placed. Am I reading that wrong?

posts.author: liketheboys
posts.body:
Glad you pointed that out, that is some weird wording.

Aside from that case probably being unlikely in practice, I think the intention of the rule is that you count where you place the track that connects the East and the West.

threads.title: Tree Society - A short review by The Meeple Guys

posts.author: TheMeepleGuys
posts.body:
In Tree Society, players work together to expand a flourishing forest community made up of various guilds, each with its own unique buildings. Every turn, players sell fruit to earn money, which theyâ€™ll need to construct new structures.



ðŸŽSelling fruit is a clever market-driven mechanicâ€”simply choose a fruit card on your board and check how many matching fruit cards are in play, both in the central market and on opponentsâ€™ boards. The more there are, the more money you earn when selling that fruit!

ðŸ«With your earnings, youâ€™ll begin constructing a building. Each guild offers different types of structures, all built in 3 sequential levels. As you progress, you may unlock instant bonuses, temporary abilities, and valuable scoring conditions. Completing all 3 levels not only earns you points but also grants you banners, which play a key role in ending the game. At the end of your turn youâ€™ll select a new fruit from the market to add to your board.



ðŸ‡Each building displays 1 to 2 banners, and once a player collects 6 banners, the game concludes. The player with the highest score wins, proving themselves the true architect of the Tree Society!ðŸ›ï¸

ðŸ’­Our thoughtsðŸ’­
ðŸƒThe game is easy to teach and quick to set up.
ðŸƒWe really enjoy the clever mechanic behind selling your fruit cards, which ensures plenty of player interaction. However we preferred playing with 3 or 4 players to fully appreciate the strategy.
ðŸƒWith a variety of buildings and unique abilities, the game presents a fun and engaging puzzle that remains accessible to all players.
ðŸƒOnly 4 out of 6 guilds are used in each game, which adds a fantastic layer of replayability and keeps things fresh.
ðŸƒTurns are quick, ensuring the game never overstays its welcome and keeps everyone engaged from start to finish.



Tree Society offers a surprising amount of gameplay in a compact box, keeping players engaged with its dynamic player interaction and a captivating puzzle as you compete to score the most points.

â­ï¸ Our rating: 7,5/10
